description: Spina bifida (SB) refers to neural tube disorders that involve the spinal region, including SB occulta and SB cystica.(1,2,3) SB is a type of spinal dysraphism, which is the term for neurological disorders that are caused by malformations of the spinal cord(21)

SB occulta: midline neural tube defect in the closure of the posterior vertebral arches and laminae; typically involves the L5–S1 region of the spinal column(1) –Occurs in 10% of the general pediatric population(1)

SB cystica: includes both meningocele and myelomeningocele; usually occurs in the lumbosacral area of the spinal column(1) –Meningocele: midline neural tube defect in which the meninges protrude through a defect in the vertebral spinal column and create a hernia cyst filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF); accounts for 5% of cases of SB cystica(1) –Myelomeningocele: the most severe form of SB,which accounts for about 95% of cases of SB cystica; meninges, fragments of bone and cartilage, and the spinal cord herniate through vertebral cleft in the spinal column or through the skin(1)

presentation signs and symptoms: Physical signs and symptoms of SB –SB occulta -Most patients are asymptomatic and have normal neurological evaluations(3) -Patient might have a patch of hair, a lipoma (benign fatty tumor), skin discoloration, or dermal sinus (a recess, cavity, or channel from the skin to the spinal cord) overlying the spinal column defect(1,2) -Sometimes associated with syringomyelia (fluid-filled sac within the spinal cord), diastematomyelia (spinal column is divided into halves by a bony or cartilaginous septum), or a tethered cord (tissue attachments that limit the movement of the spinal cord within the spinal column)(1) –SB cystica -Meningocele -A cyst-like  sac is visible outside of the body, usually at the base of the spine(2) -Inside the mass, only the meninges, not the spinal cord, protrude through the defect in the vertebral arch(2) -Most patients have a normal neurological evaluation(1) -Spinal column defects can be accompanied by syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, and/or a tethered cord(1) -Constipation or bladder dysfunction can develop as a result of enlargement of the lesion(1) -Myelomeningocele -The spinal defect might be completely exposed (SB aperta), or covered by a skin-like  membrane; typically, the meninges, and sometimes even the spinal cord, protrude through the defect in the vertebral arch and form a cyst-like sac(1,2) -Extent of neurological deficits depends on the level of the spinal defect(1) -Thoracolumbar: patient will have hypertonic bladder with normal bowel function(1) -Below L2: flaccid muscle tone, areflexic paraparesis, sensory loss in the L3–L4  dermatomes, bladder and bowel incontinence, poor anal sphincter tone that can result in rectal prolapse(1) -Below S3: bladder and bowel incontinence and anesthesia; no neurological deficits(1) -Joint deformities such as contractures, hip dislocations, and scoliosis(1) -Hydrocephalus with Chiari malformation type II occurs in up to 90% of patients with lumbosacral myelomeningocele(1,2) -Chiari malformation type II results in the extension of both cerebellar and brainstem tissue into the foramen magnum(3) -Signs and symptoms of Chiari malformation type II are intermittent obstructive or central sleep apnea, cyanosis, bradycardia, dysphagia, nystagmus, stridor, vocal cord paralysis, torticollis, opisthotonos, hypotonia, upper extremity weakness, and spasticity(3) -For detailed information about Chiari malformation, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Chiari Malformation ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709104 -Tethered cord syndrome can occur and result in loss of motor function, spasticity with joint contractures, rapid progression of scoliosis with poor posture, back pain, and bladder dysfunction(1,3) -Hydromyelia (dilatation of the central canal of the spinal cord); when symptomatic, it can result in rapidly progressive scoliosis, a change in strength or coordination of the upper and/or lower extremities, and spasticity(3) -Myelomeningocele is associated with cell migration disorders that can result in brain malformation such as heterotropia (abnormal alignment of the eyes) and schizencephaly (abnormal slits or clefts in the brain – often results in developmental delays)(1)  -Multiorgan developmental disease, including renal ageneses/anomalies, duodenal atresia, cardiac malformations, and tracheoesophageal fistulas, can occur(1)
Functional deficits associated with SB –Limited ambulation and mobility(3) –Poor eye-hand  coordination(4) –Poor handwriting skills(4)

Cognitive/speech/language signs and symptoms of SB –Individuals with SB typically have an average IQ(4) -Individuals with SB who have severe hydrocephalus have increased risk of lower than average IQs(4) –Higher grades/test performance in reading and spelling than in math -In general, the more the spinal column is damaged, the greater the chance that an individual with SB will have learning problems(4) –Reduced speech intelligibility(5) –Receptive and expressive language delays and deficits(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Family members or caregivers should be involved in both assessment and treatment.(7) They have a unique perspective and can provide information about the patient that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures

The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) needs to be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communicative functioning and developing treatment goals. The communication needs of the individual with SB should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting

Development of an individualized family services plan (IFSP; ages 0–3years) or individualized education plan (IEP) in collaboration with the parents/caregivers and school personnel for school-aged individuals with SB is essential to address potential communication and learning problems as well as possible swallowing problems in the school environment(5)
The SLP must be aware of the patient’s pain and pain tolerance levels as well as attention span, anxiety level, and any other behavioral issues

pathogenesis: In SB, the roof of the vertebral canal (i.e., the vertebral arch) over one or more of the vertebrae fails to fuse together dorsalto the spinal cord(2)–In some cases, the neural tube does not close at all, leaving neural tissue exposed; this results in necrosis of the neuraltissue(2)-This is the most severe type of SB, referred to as SB with rachischisis (also called complete SB), and the fetus does notsurvive(2)
The underlying spinal cord is not always affected by SB(2)

In SB cystica, hydrocephalus commonly occurs as a result of the spinal cord being tethered to the vertebral column duringdevelopment; the vertebral column lengthens and the tethering pulls the cerebellar tonsils down into the foramen magnum,preventing the flow of CSF out of the ventricles(2)
The severity of SB depends on the stage of development in which the failure to close occurs (i.e., earlier failure results inSB cystica and later results in SB occulta)(1)
risk factors: Nutritional deficiency in the pregnant mother (specifically folate)(1,2,3,5)
Maternal use of certain drugs (e.g., carbamazepine, valproic acid) during pregnancy(3,4,5)
Race and ethnicity(4)–SB is more common among Whites than Blacks and among Hispanics than non-Hispanics(4,5)
Maternal hyperthermia (e.g., prolonged high fevers; extended hot tub or sauna use)(3,4)

overall contraindications precautions: Latex allergy is very common in individuals with SB(3,5,6) All patients with SB should be considered at high risk for allergic reaction to natural latex and should avoid latex products beginning at birth(4,6) An individual’s response can vary from mild (e.g., watery eyes) to life-threatening  (anaphylaxis) symptoms(6) Bottle nipples can be made with latex; ensure that an infant with SB is fed from a nonlatex nipple(4) Safe alternatives to latex include silicone, plastic, nitrile, and vinyl(4)

For patients with SB and hydrocephalus, be aware of the signs and symptoms of shunt malfunction/increasing intracranial pressure and refer to the physician when appropriate; this can be a life-threatening situation(5) Infants –Bulging fontanels (soft spot)(3) –V omiting(3,4) –Irritability(3) –Change in appetite(3) –Lethargy(3) –Sunsetting eyes (paralysis of upward gaze)(3) –Seizures(3) –V ocal cord paralysis with stridor(3) –Swelling or redness along the shunt track(3) Toddlers –V omiting(3) –Lethargy(3) –Seizures(3) –Irritability(3) –Headaches(3) –Swelling or redness along the shunt track(3) School-aged  children –Change in intellect, performance, or personality(4) –Headaches(4) –Nausea(4) –Seizures(4) –V omiting(3) –Lethargy(3) –Irritability(3) –Swelling or redness along the shunt track(3) Adults –Headaches(3) –V omiting(3) –Lethargy(3) –Seizures(3) –Redness or swelling along the shunt track(3)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was SB diagnosed in the patient? Most cases of SB can be detected prenatally. Prenatal diagnosis is important so that the patient’s parents can plan for delivery in a hospital that offers neurologic closure surgery very soon after birth(3) -What type of SB has been diagnosed in the patient? What is the level of the spinal column defect? -Document the patient’s developmental and speech and language history, including milestones and delays(5,8) -Document the patient’s developmental and speech and language history, including milestones and delays(5,8) -Higher level of lesion and presence of a shunt is associated with poorer performance on childhood tests of motor skills(8) -As a group, children with SB have a slower rate of cognitive and language growth than typically developing age-matched  children(8)

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical and/or surgical management of SB to date For individuals with SB occulta who are asymptomatic and have normal neurological examinations, there is often no medical intervention(1) For most patients with meningocele, the spinal defect is covered by skin; hence, the risk of infection is low and surgery is delayed. If CSF begins to leak or the skin covering the defect is very thin, immediate surgical correction (i.e., at birth) is warranted(1) For patients with myelomeningocele, surgery for initial sac closure and placement of a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is typically performed within the first 48 hours after birth to reduce the risk of infection of the CNS(1,3) Throughout the lifespan, individuals who have VP shunts often require shunt revisions due to malfunction or obstruction(3) There have been ~400 prenatal/intrauterine surgeries worldwide for sac closure and shunt placement; however, this type of surgery is not performed routinely as there is a scarcity of data regarding risks and benefits(3,9) Multidisciplinary team approach with a primary physician, neurologist, urologist, orthopedic surgeon, neurosurgeon, physical therapist (PT), occupational therapist (OT), and SLP(1) Bladder catheterization to ensure complete emptying of the bladder and minimize renal scarring(1,3) Frequent urodynamic evaluations(1) Bowel training program with stool softeners and enemas if necessary(1) Close monitoring of function and ambulation for any worsening of clubfoot, spasticity, sensory loss, or tethered cord that might warrant neurosurgical intervention(1) Orthotics for ambulation(1) Frequent examinations of the skin to monitor for decubitus ulcer formation(1)  Factors that increase the risk of pressure ulcer formation in individuals with SB include level of lesion (higher lesions associated with greater risk), wheelchair use, urinary incontinence, presence of a shunt, above the knee orthopedic surgery, having had recent surgery, and male sex(24)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken? For individuals with SB occulta who are asymptomatic and have normal neurological examinations, there is often no pharmacological treatment(1) Patients with myelomeningocele sometimes require antiepileptic medications to control seizures(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Review any diagnostic tests that have been completed. Usual tests for this condition are the following:
MRI of the head and spine(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors that affect communication and cognitive abilities, including internal (e.g., pain) and external (e.g., noise level) distractors, communication partners, time of day, and medication use
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of the speech and language symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Individuals with SB often experience chronic pain as a result of the condition and its complications(10) -For children with SB, the Varni/Thompson Pediatric Pain Questionnaire has been used in research studies to document pain(10)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Sleep apnea is common in infants with SB(5)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. As the patient ages, new neurological and physical -Late neurological changes -VP shunt infections/malfunction(3) -Syringomyelia(3) -Symptomatic tethered cord(3) -Symptomatic Chiari malformation type II(3) -Chronic headaches(3) -Seizures(3) -Late musculoskeletal changes -Shoulder pain/rotator cuff disorders/bicipital tendonitis associated with chronic wheelchair use(3) -Charcot joints (neuropathic joint disease)(3) -Deteriorating ambulation status(3) -Renal and urologic damage -Bladder cancer (same rate of occurrence as the general population, but with earlier age of onset and poorer prognosis)(3)  -Renal damage (however, with proper ongoing urologic care up to 80% of adults with SB can maintain normal renal function and social continence)(3) -Fertility/sexuality/reproductive issues -Fertility in women with SB is generally unaffected(3) -Higher incidence of complications during pregnancy than in the general population(3) -Most men with myelomeningocele are infertile; genital sensation is also usually compromised(3,5) -Early-onset  puberty is common in individuals with SB(5,11) -Sex education for adolescents with SB should include information related to latex-free condoms(11)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document current respiratory status as well as any history of intubation, mechanical ventilation, pneumonia/respiratory infection, asthma, or supplemental oxygen -Sleep apnea is common in infants with SB(5) -As an individual with SB ages, respiratory status can be compromised by reduced mobility and increased spinal curvature (such as scoliosis or kyphosis)(5)Individuals with SB are at increased risk for depression and anxiety compared with the general population(4,10) -Low self-esteem,  social isolation, and lack of social support are common in young patients with SB(4,5) -Document history of depression, anxiety, or other psychosocial disturbance -Document any symptoms of depression or anxiety, including sadness that persists over time, difficulty concentrating, insomnia, headaches, and nausea(4) -Physical causes of these symptoms (e.g., shunt malfunction) must be ruled out prior to diagnosing depression or anxiety in the patient (4) -Individuals with SB (especially those with myelomeningocele and hydrocephalus) are easily distracted, have difficulty adapting to new situations, tend to be withdrawn, and can be less predictable and/or attentive than typically developing peers(3) -Having a child with SB can be very difficult for parents and other family members due to sadness about the condition, financial burdens, and family disruption(5) -If patient or patient’s family reports symptoms of depression, anxiety, or other psychosocial or behavioral disturbance, or if the family is experiencing high levels of conflict, refer to mental health professional for additional assessment(28)Document hearing ability as well as need for/use of hearing aid(s) -Hearing loss can occur in individuals with SB as an adverse side effect of a VP shunt due to disruption of cochlear hydrodynamics as the result of reduced perilymph pressure(5,12) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has a speech and/or language disorder previously been diagnosed in the patient? Is there a history of feeding or swallowing problems?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Children with SB are at high risk for vitamin D deficiency(29)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the speech or swallowing impairment interfere with progress in school or ability to function at home or in a work setting? Does the patient socialize with peers?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: -Document if the patient is using adaptive equipment and what type, such as wheelchairs, orthotics, hearing aids, or glasses(13) -Individuals with SB usually use one or more types of assistive or adaptive equipment to increase mobility and community participation(13) -As the individual with SB ages, he or she often transitions from ambulation to wheeled mobility(13) -Determine the effect of the patient’s speech, language, and cognitive deficits on participation in school, social, and occupational activities
social and occupational history.living environment: Obtain information about the patient’s home environment and living situation, including with whom patient lives and communicates(e.g., siblings, caregivers). Are there pets in the home? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; are any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note BMI; individuals with SB are at increased risk for obesity due to lower metabolic rate and lower levels of energy expenditure.(3,5) Individuals with higher-level lesions have higher risk of obesity(30)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document the use of alternative or augmentative communication (AAC) –For patients with severe communication impairment, it might be appropriate to assess ability to use AAC to increase functional communication –Individuals with SB often have very poor handwriting and therefore utilize assistive technology for written output(13) –Assistive technology for cognitive support is also commonly used by individuals with SB, including memory aids/ reminders for medications, electronic time prompts/alarms, word-prediction  software to improve rate of and spelling in written output, and handheld dictionaries(13,17) –For detailed information regarding the assessment for and use of AAC in speech therapy, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.posture: Document postural deficits (e.g., scoliosis, kyphosis) as they relate to speech production. As an individual with SB ages, respiratory status can be compromised by increased spinal curvature, which can impact respiration for speech tasks(5)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisComplete a quality of life measure. Myelomeningocele is associated with reduced health-related quality of life in children.(32) Authors of a systemic review of children with myelomeningocele found that health-related  quality of life declines with age, with psychosocial well-being,  self-esteem,  and peer relationships being most severely affected after
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Although SB itself does not cause speech and language delays, individuals with SB have increased risk of speech and language problems due to CNS infections, increased intracranial pressure, repeated hospitalizations, and limited socialization(5)Assess articulation skills(5,18) -Individuals with SB with hydrocephalus, especially those with Chiari malformation type II, are at increased risk for cerebellar damage, which can lead to ataxic dysarthria(18) -Characteristics of dysarthric speech associated with SB with hydrocephalus include reduced intelligibility, poor fluency of speech, abnormal prosody, and reduced vocal intensity(18) -Prevalence of dysarthria increases with age in individuals with SB(18)  -Complete formal and informal assessments of articulation/motor speech to determine the presence and severity of a speech disorderstandardized measure for differential diagnosis for adult dysarthria(18) -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of ataxic dysarthria, see Clinical Review…Dysarthria, Ataxic ;T708849Assess expressive and receptive language skills(5) -Pragmatics are often impaired in individuals with SB(3,15,19)(3,19) -Verbosity, including extraneous, inappropriate, and irrelevant information in conversational speech(3) -Difficulty staying on topic(3) -Overuse of social phrases in conversation; overly familiar manner of speaking(3,19) -Individuals with SB often have reduced fluency in naming tasks(18) -When a patient with SB has an average level of intelligence, he or she is less likely to demonstrate characteristics of cocktail party syndrome in conversational speech(19) -Children with SB often show reduced comprehension of figurative language(19,20) -Many individuals with SB will have intact abilities with respect to vocabulary, morphology, and syntax(16,19) -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of language disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on language disordersV ocal cord paralysis and stridor are common in individuals with SB, especially infants and young children.(5) Assess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance; if there are specific concerns regarding voice, refer to otolaryngologist for complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies prior to completing a full evaluation -For detailed information on voice disorders, see the series of the Clinical Reviews on this topicRule out or identify atypical speech dysfluencies (stuttering) -Individuals with SB have an increased incidence of dysfluent speech(18) -For detailed information on disorders of fluency, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicChildren with SB are usually able to develop single-word  reading skills in early elementary school; however, in later elementary school and throughout adulthood, individuals with SB have difficulty with reading comprehension(4,16) -Early screening of reading comprehension is recommended for patients with SB(4) -Reading comprehension can be assessed formally through an appropriate subtest of a language test or informally by having the patient read and summarize a story or paragraph(4) -Expressive written language skills are often much more impaired than expressive spoken language skills(13) -If problems with reading comprehension are evident, refer to a learning disabilities or reading specialist for further assessment and interventionT709076
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Assess the patient’s oral motor skills during speech, imitation of motor movements, diadochokinesis tasks, and strength testing tasks in order to identify or rule out a motor-based  speech disorder
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Briefly assess cognitive functioning; document the results of any neuropsychological tests that have been completed to date –Most (~70%) individuals with SB have normal intelligence; however, cognitive function can be affected by hydrocephalus or CNS infections such as meningitis and encephalitis that result from SB(1,3) –Verbal IQ is often higher than performance IQ in individuals with SB(3) –Cognitive deficits typical of individuals with SB include reduced memory and verbal learning skills, reduced executive functioning skills, poor divided attention, and slowed reaction speed(14) -In a study conducted in the Netherlands with 14 subjects, researchers found that individuals with SB who had lower levels of overall physical activity also performed more poorly on tests of executive functioning(14) –Spatial knowledge is reduced in individuals with SB compared to typically developing peers matched for age and performance IQ(15,16) –There is a higher incidence of learning disabilities and seizures in individuals with SB compared to the general population(1,5) -In school, individuals with SB have more difficulty with math and visual perceptual tasks than do typically developing peers(3,16) –For individuals with cognitive impairment, refer to learning disabilities specialist or neuropsychologist for further evaluation and treatment(1)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: A comprehensive speech-language evaluation and the reason for the initial referral will determine the need for speech therapy and the nature of the specific treatment goals(19)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out other causes of symptoms prior to diagnosing SB
prognosis: Authors of a study conducted in the United States used data from 2,054 patients with SB collected between 2009 and 2012 on the National Spina Bifida Patient Registry (NSBPR) to determine factors that affected 4 specific functional outcomes: bowel continence, urinary continence, mobility, and presence of pressure ulcers. Analysis of the data indicated that sex (male associated with worse outcomes),race (non-Hispanic  Blacks had poorer outcomes), and insurance status (non-private insurance associated with worse outcomes) affected overall functional outcomes. Additionally, as patients with SB aged, they were less likely to be ambulatory and more likely to have pressure ulcers(25)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer the patient to other disciplines as appropriate given his or her individual needs Primary physician/neurologist for signs of shunt malfunction, CNS infection, or increased intracranial pressure Urologist for bladder training programs and catheterization needs Orthopedic surgeon for musculoskeletal problems (these typically worsen with age) Neurosurgeon for shunt placement/malfunction/revision PT and OT for ambulation, ADLs, strength training, mobility needs, and assistive and adaptive equipment
treatment summary: Involve the patient’s family in treatment as much as possible, including parental observation of and participation in therapy sessions, take-home  practice exercises, and/or regular therapist/parent conferences
Choosing therapy goals that focus on academic and social language might help patients be more successful and functional in school, occupational, and social settings

Treatment approaches for specific areas of need (e.g., dysarthria, fluency, pragmatics) are determined based on the results of a thorough speech-language  evaluation and the patient’s personality and response to trial therapy. For detailed information on therapy for specific speech and language disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on each topic

Goal Management Training (GMT) : GMT is an interactive therapy program for improving executive functioning in patients with neurological impairment. GMT was initially developed by researchers in the United Kingdom, but has been studied by researchers in many countries including Canada, South Africa, and the United States. As part of GMT, patients are trained in mindfulness and learn to think “Stop!” before and during tasks to increase attention to task and task organization. In an RCT conducted in Norway with 38 adults with SB, researchers found that GMT resulted in significant improvements in both executive functioning and mental health aspects of health-related  quality of life (e.g., coping skills). Although GMT is promising, researchers recommended additional research with larger sample sizes(22,23) . improved receptive and expressive langua: Formal and informal assessments of language abilities

maintenance or prevention: Taking folic acid prior to and during pregnancy will not guarantee that a child will not have SB; however, it can reduce the risk of SB in the developing fetus.(4,26) Prevalence of SB is significantly lower in countries that require fortification of food with folic acid compared to countries without these regulations(31) All women of childbearing age should take a supplement containing 400 mcg (0.4 mg) of folic acid daily(1,4) Women with SB or who have had a child or pregnancy affected by SB should take 4,000 mcg (4.0 mg) of folic acid for 1 to 3 months prior to becoming pregnant(4) Women who are taking valproic acid, carbamazepine, methotrexate, sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim, and/or other medications that can alter folate metabolism will probably need a higher daily dose of folic acid and should discuss this with their primary physician or gynecologist(1)

Patients with SB who have had a reaction to latex should: Wear a medical alert bracelet or necklace(4) Carry auto-injectable  epinephrine(4,5) Carry sterile nonlatex gloves and other nonlatex medical items for emergencies(4)
